description:
Changes are failing the gate-tempest-*-full gate due to an error message in the logs.
The error message is like

2014-01-18 20:13:19.437 | Log File: n-cpu
2014-01-18 20:13:20.482 | 2014-01-18 20:04:05.189 ERROR nova.compute.manager [req-25a1842c-ce9a-4035-8975-651f6ee5ddfc tempest.scenario.manager-tempest-1060379467-user tempest.scenario.manager-tempest-1060379467-tenant] [instance: 0b1c1b55-b520-4ff2-bac2-8457ba3f4b6a] Error: iSCSI device not found at /dev/disk/by-path/ip-127.0.0.1:3260-iscsi-iqn.2010-10.org.openstack:volume-a6e86002-dc25-4782-943b-58cc0c68238d-lun-1

Here's logstash for the query:

http://logstash.openstack.org/#

shows several failures starting at 2014-01-17T14:00:00

Maybe tempest is doing something that generates the ERROR message and then isn't accepting the error message it should?
Or nova is logging an error message when it shouldn't?
title: n-cpu 'iSCSI device not found' log causes gate-tempest-dsvm-*-full to fail

comments.content:
Changes are failing the gate-tempest-*-full gate due to an error message in the logs.
The error message is like

2014-01-18 20:13:19.437 | Log File: n-cpu
2014-01-18 20:13:20.482 | 2014-01-18 20:04:05.189 ERROR nova.compute.manager [req-25a1842c-ce9a-4035-8975-651f6ee5ddfc tempest.scenario.manager-tempest-1060379467-user tempest.scenario.manager-tempest-1060379467-tenant] [instance: 0b1c1b55-b520-4ff2-bac2-8457ba3f4b6a] Error: iSCSI device not found at /dev/disk/by-path/ip-127.0.0.1:3260-iscsi-iqn.2010-10.org.openstack:volume-a6e86002-dc25-4782-943b-58cc0c68238d-lun-1

Here's logstash for the query:

http://logstash.openstack.org/#

shows several failures starting at 2014-01-17T14:00:00

Maybe tempest is generating an ERROR nad not accepting an error message it should?
Or nova is logging an error message when it shouldn't?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~blk-u

---

Using logstash with some of these other messages:

message:"ISCSI volume not yet found at: vda. Will rescan & retry.  Try number: 2" AND filename:"logs/screen-n-cpu.txt"
-- all failures

message:"ISCSI volume not yet found at: vda. Will rescan & retry.  Try number: 1" AND filename:"logs/screen-n-cpu.txt"
-- some successes
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~blk-u

comments.content:
when I switch to

message:"ISCSI volume not yet found at: vda. Will rescan & retry.  Try number: 0" AND filename:"logs/screen-n-cpu.txt"

then there's even more successes, 41% successful now
vs 10% success for "Try number: 1" and 0% sucess for "Try number: 2"
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~blk-u

comments.content:
Here's the code, it's looping a few times waiting for ready: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/virt/libvirt/volume.py?id=1e74b8677a756653a6e851710f1ead8db7842391#n301

the default number of retries is the num_iscsi_scan_tries config option, which defaults to 3.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~blk-u

comments.content: I might suggest increasing the number of retries but the sleep goes up by n^2... that's a lot of sleeping.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~blk-u

comments.content:
This might be intersting -- syslog : http://logs.openstack.org/75/64575/15/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full/884bf53/logs/syslog.txt.gz

Jan 18 20:06:51 devstack-precise-rax-dfw-1129843 iscsid: connection8:0 is operational now

So n-cpu log shows an error at 20:04:02.853, and there's another call to iscsiadm --rescan at 20:06:51.299, and there's a message in syslog showing a connection is operational.

So maybe waiting longer is necessary on the test system?

comments.content:
So nevermind on the e-r query being wrong or not, apparently e-r didn't report on the failure since there is a current jenkins scp race bug where the logs don't come back so e-r can't check the logs to report the failure.

Looking at nova commits merged around 1/17, this one stands out to me as being a suspect:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/0530e02004578a36039111beddf472fcf3e48df6

comments.content:
Digging through the logs here:

http://logs.openstack.org/85/59685/10/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full/216c951/logs/

Using iqn.2010-10.org.openstack:volume-4b0ba348-afd5-4286-b030-809de0421a85 as my key, and keeping in mind this change:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/58599/

The test creates volume 1 from an image, then creates a snapshot from that volume and then creates volume 2 from the snapshot.  The test then fails to boot an instance from volume 2.

Looking at the cinder volume logs, I see volume 2 is created here:

http://logs.openstack.org/85/59685/10/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full/216c951/logs/screen-c-vol.txt.gz#_2014-01-18_17_46_29_886

The new tgtadm --update code in cinder is called here (2 seconds later):

http://logs.openstack.org/85/59685/10/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full/216c951/logs/screen-c-vol.txt.gz#_2014-01-18_17_46_31_847

Nova times out here (~22 seconds later):

http://logs.openstack.org/85/59685/10/gate/gate-tempest-dsvm-postgres-full/216c951/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?level=ERROR#_2014-01-18_17_46_53_229

The odd thing is I don't see anything in syslog for that volume.  From the cinder logs, the target information for the volume is this:

Target 11: iqn.2010-10.org.openstack:volume-4b0ba348-afd5-4286-b030-809de0421a85
    System information:
        Driver: iscsi
        State: ready
    I_T nexus information:
    LUN information:
        LUN: 0
            Type: controller
            SCSI ID: IET     000b0000
            SCSI SN: beaf110
            Size: 0 MB, Block size: 1
            Online: Yes
            Removable media: No
            Readonly: No
            Backing store type: null
            Backing store path: None
            Backing store flags: 
        LUN: 1
            Type: disk
            SCSI ID: IET     000b0001
            SCSI SN: beaf111
            Size: 1074 MB, Block size: 512
            Online: Yes
            Removable media: No
            Readonly: No
            Backing store type: rdwr
            Backing store path: /dev/stack-volumes/volume-4b0ba348-afd5-4286-b030-809de0421a85
            Backing store flags: 
    Account information:
    ACL information:
        ALL

There is nothing in syslog about target 11.

(4:03:46 PM) jgriffith: mriedem: but then the next entry is a delete

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~john-griffith

comments.content:
The revert of the tempest test hit the same failure, so this is still breaking:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69599/

I've posted some notes in the review, it looks like after we get past the first retry (5 seconds in), we never get the device, so I'm not sure that increasing the timeout is the solution.

We need to figure out what kind of diagnostics we can dump when this fails to get a better idea of what's going on with tgtadm/cinder at the point of failure, but I don't know what that is.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content:
Turns out this does appear to be a side effect of commit: e2e0ed80799c1ba04b37278996a171fc74b6f9eb
does seem to be the root of the problem.  It appears that the initialize is in some cases doing a delete of 
the targets.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~john-griffith

comments.content:
Here is John's patch to revert the change mentioned above:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/69787/
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content:
Reviewed:  https://review.openstack.org/69787
Committed: https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/cinder/commit/?id=0132be46bc9b4bb1b3bf77a623cc1d3b7e9307ea
Submitter: Jenkins
Branch:    master

commit 0132be46bc9b4bb1b3bf77a623cc1d3b7e9307ea
Author: john-griffith <email address hidden>
Date:   Tue Jan 28 21:30:59 2014 -0700

    Revert initialize_connection changes
    
    A change was merged that reusulted in interittent
    gate failures.  It seems that in certain cases the
    intitialize is doing an update targets and is
    deleting the existing targets and not recreating them.
    
    The idea of this patch was to fix up the iscis targets
    for cases where volumes are extended.
    
    A better solution is in progress that will remove the
    target creation from the create_volume process altogether.
    
    Currently we seem to have create_export, ensure_export and
    now initialize that all are designed to do very similar
    things.
    
    A bug has been filed to address this and will attempt
    to collapse these functions to be done at attach time.
    
    This particular patch in essence reverts two patches:
    commit: 18f8f5be94aae3b1747b143479ea1b188872f000
    commit: a9267644ee09591e2d642d6c1204d94a9fdd8c82
    
    Change-Id: Ib615847f3cbeb74b1e4416d51730162ad1d07a40
    Closes-Bug: 1270608
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hudson-openstack

comments.content:
With the latest patch (the revert) I think this is finally gone, no hits since that merged:

http://logstash.openstack.org/#
